at adult twins where both of the twins are

they can figure out from that design that

upon these models, of the environmental effect

87.45.text:
to choose one study that you've either done

that this matters and it's not just easily

all this. Christina: I saw the other day after

And I found that story so poignant because

mother that he had this heartbreak. He had

by their fathers described just this empty

you could also see what we were talking about,

turned him to this superachiever. That’s

how much hurt he is in his case. Brad: And

to fight harder and do better, but I'm just

the story goes much... Christina: That's what

just one factor that he has noticed in his

you think about how the village is constituted

496.70.text:
to at least be honest about them, the risks

no matter what happens. But the question is

21st century that acknowledges the lots of

most homes with married dads, dads are doing

Still not enough. Brad: How do we create a

with working class and poor families, we're

now, doesn't mean he can't play an important

to understand that he could provide in other

and to appreciate that men's role extends

to the family. So that's the thing we need

612.45.text:
century marriage model. Christina: And I remember

touch with your feelings, and still do that

it seems like they set a standard of fatherhood

That's something to hold onto as well. Christina:

for kids, yeah. Christina: ...bad for kids.

if we look at the Millennials, many who come

in some outcomes, we're doing better now than

unequal parental resources economically, and

this is a precious resource and it's not there

make is that kids would be doing that much

striking things that I have seen is work of

to bridge this marriage divide and bridge

901.15.text:
I have to agree with you because even in my

there was a time where you could graduate

at Harvard Graduate School of Education that

Dream is education beyond high school. And

1001.57.text:
Right, right. That's a great point. I think

talked with the way in which...when you make

look, we may not have really great options

my point is, well, look, if that's where you

to their mothers. The boy is never raised

this pattern, this cycle. Christina: It just

1035.66.text:
"Oh, it's all right. The men just aren't worth

1039.85.text:
for us is how do we help working class and

track find their identities in terms of educational

1057.67.text:
when it comes to vocational education, for

1060.38.text:
That's exactly right. In Australia, they did

boys of all social classes, but they were

1069.97.text:
middle class poor boys. And almost without

with their classes in high school. They just

will keep you in school?" And they said, "Something

have models of excellence in vocational education.

a place to place kids that people thought

1100.01.text:
schools combined academics. I visited a high

New York. It's one of the most inspiring places

kind of section of Queens. You go in there,

academic classes in order to tinker with...I

out in the parking lot. And to tinker with

to take these other courses. So they work

they can have jobs in an airplane mechanics

draw poor and working class kids from all
backgrounds across New York City, and it's

1144.32.text:
just such an obvious solution. I just want
to go back because I have a couple of more

1150.22.text:
questions from these critics, the family structure

1161.08.text:
In Europe...here you are encouraging marriage

1168.01.text:
unfortunate consequences, but in Europe, marriage,

1174.92.text:
popular than it once was or less common than

it's becoming the norm in France, I think,

1190.90.text:
Maybe we should be getting the same social

1197.39.text:
problem." Brad: Well, it's really the case

1201.49.text:
minimizing any kind of economic impacts of

that even in Europe, kids who are born to

in Northwestern Europe, are still more likely

1220.47.text:
they turn 12 compared to kids who are born

1225.05.text:
and elsewhere. So, what's interesting about

1229.43.text:
not a Christian thing, it's a human thing.
So we see obviously marriage in China, in

1234.87.text:
India, in Egypt, in Europe. It's this thing

1242.95.text:
adult relationships, then integrate typically

1247.98.text:
And to do so with some rituals and some vows

1254.50.text:
members and entry into this new state in your
life. And so not surprising, whether you're

1259.07.text:
in Sweden or in Saudi Arabia or in China or
in Columbia or in the United States or in

1265.38.text:
Uruguay, you would tend to see more stability

1271.23.text:
than families that are formed around other

1275.44.text:
Christina: Just the way you described it,
so you see it as essential or a critical part

1281.83.text:
of the human ecosystem and throughout the...and
just as we learned that we have to certainly

1289.00.text:
hesitate and ask questions before we just
happily take all the rivers and, "Oh, we don't

1295.09.text:
need this system. Let's change the course

ecological destruction. This can happen when

with a tradition, an institution. And so that's

1315.87.text:
kind of a Burkean view to some extent, but

1319.10.text:
yeah, there's a human ecology out there, and

1324.26.text:
either at the family or at the neighborhood

1328.06.text:
here in United States for instance, kids pay

1333.35.text:
boys pay a big price when the neighborhood
is dysfunctional, when the families aren't

1338.64.text:
being formed around two parents, etc. So,

this that's important to be attentive to.
Christina: I have a final question that goes

1347.14.text:
back to my experience at Stanford. They were
so unhappy when I talked about the need for

1353.41.text:
fathers and family stability. It occurred
to me that maybe...one thing is maybe they

1363.73.text:
thought I was being judgmental. Maybe they
heard me, although I didn't say it, but maybe

1367.79.text:
they heard me saying that you should have

don't. Of course, I don't even believe that,
but my question to you is when you teach your

1379.94.text:
classes and you bring up the topic of the
divorce revolution and single families, single-parent

1390.04.text:
families, what do you do about this? I'm sure

1396.00.text:
the fact that some kids are going to...many
of your students, these days, more than half

1401.42.text:
may come from broken families, and they may

1408.13.text:
some way or shortchanged, and people don't

1420.72.text:
without appearing to be telling people that

a great question. I think there are three

1434.53.text:
that are helpful in this regard. The first

mother and I'm very clear about sort of saying,

1445.89.text:
experienced this myself." So that's helpful

to some extent. A second thing is to actually
point out...I quiz my kids anonymously with

1456.96.text:
these little electronic clickers we can use

1460.74.text:
some of the classes that I teach at UVA, about

1466.01.text:
